head.title: Relief Expert Missing in Chechnya Is Among MacArthur Grant Recipients

hedline.hl1: Relief Expert Missing in Chechnya Is Among MacArthur Grant Recipients

block.p: Frederick C. Cuny, an international relief expert who has been missing in Chechnya since April, was among 24 people awarded grants yesterday by The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

Other fellows chosen for what is popularly called the genius program include the writers Sandra Cisneros and Octavia Butler, Virginia Hamilton, the first children's author to receive the fellowship, the artist Cindy Sherman, the composer and choreographer Meredith Monk, and a variety of scientists, historians and social scientists.
Frederick C. Cuny, an international relief expert who has been missing in Chechnya since April, was among 24 people awarded grants yesterday by The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

Other fellows chosen for what is popularly called the genius program include the writers Sandra Cisneros and Octavia Butler, Virginia Hamilton, the first children's author to receive the fellowship, the artist Cindy Sherman, the composer and choreographer Meredith Monk, and a variety of scientists, historians and social scientists.
The list of 9 men and 15 women includes people with interests in feminism, minorities and evolutionary biology. All except one are in their 40's or 50's.

The program rewards creative people with unrestricted five-year grants of $30,000 to $75,000 a year. Despite the genius moniker attached to the program, MacArthur executives prefer to describe the fellows as hard-working experts who often push the boundaries of their fields in ways that others will follow.

"These awards are a reminder of the importance of seeing as broadly as possible, of being willing to live outside of a comfort zone and of keeping your nerve endings open," said Catharine Stimpson, director of the awards program.
The amount of the grant depends on age, with older recipients getting more money; all get free health insurance as well.

Mr. Cuny, 50, was sent to the breakaway Russian region of Chechnya by the Soros Foundation to assess the humanitarian needs there. Russian forces have been trying to put down a secessionist movement in the region, and the circumstances surrounding his disappearance are unclear.

"There are a number of people who do the work he did," said Aryeh Neier, president of the Soros Foundation, which is based in New York. "But he brought a particularly creative grasp of the technological factors, the humanitarian needs and the political context."
Noting that Mr. Cuny was last heard from more than two months ago, Mr. Neier said he was still hopeful but also apprehensive, and said that F.B.I. had joined in the search.
If Mr. Cuny is not found alive, the award will go unclaimed.

With yesterday's group, MacArthur has named 458 people to its fellows program, which started in 1981. Of the previous recipients, 330 are men and 104 are women. The Chicago-based foundation, which has assets of about $3 billion, has put more than $140 million into the program, which is only one of many programs it finances.
The award winners and excerpts from MacArthur's descriptions of their work follow.
ALLISON ANDERS , 40, Los Angeles: $255,000. Independent film director and screenwriter who tells stories of the underrepresented segments of American society.

JED Z. BUCHWALD , 46, Cambridge, Mass.: $285,000. Professor of history of science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who examines the history of science in terms of its great ideas and the figures who generate them.
OCTAVIA BUTLER, 48, Pasadena, Calif.: $295,000. Writer who brings elements of African and African-American spiritualism, mysticism and mythology to her complex works of science fiction.
SANDRA CISNEROS, 40, San Antonio: $255,000. Writer whose novels, poems, short stories and and essays reflect working-class Hispanic life in the United States.
SANDY CLOSE, 52, San Francisco: $315,000. Executive editor, Pacific News Service, a nonprofit news service that has been cited for producing groundbreaking journalism.

FREDERICK C. CUNY , 50, Dallas: $305,000. Chairman, Intertect Relief and Reconstruction Corporation. A disaster relief specialist who is said to bring order to crisis and chaos, from Kuwait and Iraq to Somalia.

SHARON B. EMERSON , 49, Salt Lake City: $300,000. Research professor, University of Utah. A biologist with broad interests in evolution and ecology, whose work has shown that evolution occurs in systematic ways only partly related to ecological function.

RICHARD FOREMAN , 58, New York: $345,000. Artistic director, playwright, Ontological-Hysteric Theater. A theorist, he is cited for his original vision and helping to shape American avant-garde theater.
ALMA GUILLERMOPRIETO , 46, New York: $285,000. Writer and journalist whose books and essays document modern Latin America for the English-speaking reader.
VIRGINIA HAMILTON , 59, Yellow Springs, Ohio: $350,000. Writer who has woven black folk tales and narratives of African-American life into her many children's books.

DONALD HOPKINS , 53, Chicago: $320,000. Consultant, Global 2000 program. A public health scientist who has devoted his career to eradicating preventable diseases, he is now leading an effort to eradicate Guinea worm disease.

SUSAN WERNER KIEFFER , 52, West Vancouver, B.C.: $315,000. Professor, department of geological sciences, University of British Columbia. A geologist and planetary scientist, she was the first to describe the physics and chemistry involved in the eruptions on Jupiter's moon Io.
ELIZABETH LE COMPTE , 51, New York: $310,000. Director, The Wooster Group. A theater director who integrates media and texts into the theatrical environment.

PATRICIA NELSON LIMERICK , 44, Boulder, Colo.: $275,000. Professor of history, University of Colorado. Her work on the American West includes the stories of women's history, ethnic histories, and environmental history.

MICHAEL MARLETTA , 44, Ann Arbor, Mich.: $275,000. Professor of medicinal and biological chemisty, University of Michigan. His work on the biosynthesis of nitric oxide has influenced the treatment of toxic shock syndrome.

PAMELA ANNE MATSON , 41, Stanford, Calif.: $260,000. Professor of environmental science, University of California at Berkeley. She pioneered much of the research into the role of land-use changes on global warming, analyzing the effects of greenhouse gas emissions resulting from tropical deforestation.

SUSAN McCLARY , 48, Los Angeles: $295,000. Professor, University of California at Los Angeles. A musicologist who explores the relationship between human experience and music and relates the creation of musical works to their social contexts.
MEREDITH MONK , 52, New York: $315,000. A composer, vocalist, filmmaker, theatrical director and choreographer whose company, The House, has been dedicated to inter- disciplinary performance.

ROSALIND POLLACK PETCHESKY , 52, New York: $315,000. Professor of political science and women's studies, Hunter College. A political scientist who is a leading theorist on international reproductive rights, as well as the founder of the International Reproductive Rights Research Action Group.

JOEL ROGERS , 43, Madison, Wis.: $270,000. Professor of law, political science and sociology, University of Wisconsin. As an organizer and activist, he is the architect of several initiatives that bring together labor, community, business and government leaders to develop a new model for worker training.

CINDY SHERMAN , 41, New York: $260,000. Artist. Her photographs of herself in different costumes and poses have challenged traditional notions about identity, social stereotypes, and artistic representation.

BRYAN STEVENSON , 35, Montgomery, Ala.: $230,000. Executive director, Alabama Capital Representation Resource Center. A lawyer and human rights advocate who has devoted his career to fighting the death penalty.

NICHOLAS STRAUSFELD , 52, Tucson, Ariz.: $315,000. Professor of neurobiology, of entomology and of ecology and evolutionary biology, University of Arizona. An expert on the brains of insects, his work has been critical in understanding how flies see and maneuver.

RICHARD WHITE , 48, Seattle: $295,000. Professor of history, University of Washington. He has played an important role in three areas of inquiry: environmental history, Native American history, and the new Western history.
